Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2009 11:49AM nkrun wrote: I hear ya notinvincible.  I was recently diagnosed and had most of my scans a few weeks ago.  After the new year I have a bone scan because a suspicious spot appeared on a PET scan.  My hip has been bugging me for a long time and I often joked that it is probably bone cancer.  I realized now that was not funny. I also have two more MRI guided biopsies because the scan also showed my cancer has spread to the right and the left tumor is bigger than thought. My port gets installed on the 13th and I start chemo on the 14th. The way I look at it is that I have basically no control over most of it except for my attitude. I find little things to hold on to that make me look at  the situation through a different lens, however cynical they may be. I've never been much of a pot smoker so my latest encouraging thought is that maybe I can a medical marijuana card and re-live  my wild youth. I would definitely be the coolest, baldest mom in the neighborhood. Hey what ever works right.
Posts.Title: Just diadnosed and petrified SPoole Frankie_

Posts.Content: Oct 27, 2010 02:23AM nkrun wrote: congrats to all those who have finished. I have 2 more boosts and will be done.  My skin did really well up until this weekend. Under my breast is second degree burns with open blisters. The boosts are on my nipple and boy does it hurt.  Kinda feels like the first few weeks of breast feeding.  Not sure if my rad clinic has mugs or certificates but I will get to ring the bell. Can't wait. 10 months of cancer treatment and I'm getting ready for the whole s*it show to be over. I have weekly herceptin infusions until April but those just seem like my normal routine.  Doesn't cancer treatment especially radiation seem so 1900's. Really burning is state of the art?????

Posts.Content: Jul 15, 2010 12:26PM - edited Jul 15, 2010 01:14PM by nkrun Love reading posts about surgery and recovery. I finally have my surgery confirmed for July 29th. After much thought and research, I've decided to go with a lumpectomy. My recent MRI showed that most of the tumors are gone with the exception of one which shrunk from 6 cm to 1.2 cm. My BS is my PS and she is 100% confident that I will only have a small incision.  So much for getting those awesome new perky boobs. I will also have a lymph node dissection on the left side which will give me only one drain. The plan is only one night in the hospital. I got a scrpt for a cami which I understand I can get at the local Nordstroms.  Life is good and I am looking forward to the surgery being behind me.

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2010 10:59PM nkrun wrote: I have a question for anyone who is still out there.  Has anyone experienced swelling around the site where an axillary node dissection drain was removed? My surgery was 4 weeks ago and the drain removed  2 weeks ago. Today I noticed what looks like a 3rd breast on the side of my chest at the drainage site. Its the weekend and the docs are not in and Im not sure if I need to call the on call doc. The lump does not hurt, just swollen.  Ironically I was radiation tatooed near the drain site on Wednesday. Not sure that has anything to do with the swelling. Of course I tossed all my post op literature.

Posts.Title: September 2010 Rads dutchgirl6 Teka

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2010 08:10PM - edited Sep 16, 2010 08:12PM by nkrun I officially started radiation on Tuesday so today will be day 3. My doctor prescribed xclair creme to be applied 3x/day during radiation to prevent irritation. I can even wear it before rad. Onc Rad says it is the only topical solution that can be applied to my skin before rad. So far no irritation but I'm sure it is too early. One downside is that insurance does not cover this cream and it is $70 tube. Regarding bras-I got a prescription and complete insurance reimbursement for post surgical/rad bras.  You may want to ask you insurance company if you are covered. I have 2 very soft cotton front opening bras. Cannot recall the brand name. They may not be the prettiest undergarment on the market but they are sure comfortable and not to mention Free. I'm in the middle of my training for the 3-day walk in November and very concerned about how much I should actually be walking while going thru rad.  I've managed maintain a decent training schedule during chemo and surgery but now the recommended training miles are getting pretty intense.  Last week I walked over 40 miles. I feel ok but I fear that the cumulative effect of rad and walking may take its toll.  The only advice from the rad/onc is do as much as you are able and be prepared that you maynot be able to do the walk.   Has anyone else experienced fatigue from rad?
Posts.Title: September 2010 Rads dutchgirl6 Teka

At this point I know I will need my lymph nodes on the affected side removed but not sure what type of breast surgery is ahead of me. I will also need radiation after I heal from from the surgery.
Posts.Title: JULY MASTECTOMY orchidgal rosesrx

Posts.Content: Jul 10, 2010 07:03PM nkrun wrote: Thanks rosesrx and sespebadger for the tips on the cami's. I called my insurance company and they said I need a prescription from the PS before they will pay. I have my preop appointment with the PS on Tuesday so I will be sure to ask. Thanks calamtykel for sharing the scar project. I have not decided on which type of surgery I will be getting so seeing these beautiful women with all different types of scars help me to not be so afraid. I see that most are getting BMX. Based on previous conversations with my PS/BS I have a feeling she will try to steer me into getting a lumpectomy on the left side.  She was pretty adamant about not getting a bmx.  I see most of the July sisters and most every BS survivor I meet is getting BMX. Is this all about piece of mind or did your PS/BS recommend it???? orchidgal-Love the MMJ story. When I was diagnosed I ask my onc if I could get a prescription and she said "I'm not that kind of doctor".  It has been about 30 years since I enjoyed the MJ and I seriously considered partaking during this whole cancer ordeal.  That is until my 18 y/o son decided to get his MMJ card. My husband and I are livid about this. I guess now I would feel like a hypocrite. Darn teenagers! Hats off to all you strong July sisters out there.  I love love love reading  your brave stories. I'm glad I found this group to ease my anxiousness about the upcoming surgery. I am also grateful to be at the end of the month so I can learn from all of you. And for that I thank you very much. I just finished reading "The Definitive Guide to Cancer" An integrative Approach to Prevention, Treatment and Healing" by Lise N Alschuler and Karolyn Gazella. Good book similar to "The Anticancer Diet".  I'm really trying to be the best patient ever so I can beat this and to never have it reoccur. In my strive for anticancer perfection, I think I zapped all the fun out of my life. There has  to be a happy medium!!!! Most of my adult life, I lived a natural healthy active lifestyle so I struggle with what tweaks need to be made to heal and prevent recurrence. Can I really live without the triple crown-wine, coffee and stress?
Posts.Title: JULY MASTECTOMY orchidgal rosesrx

Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2010 11:47AM nkrun wrote: Orchidgal Thanks for sharing your story and the great words of encouragement. Wow- now I understand why others are getting bmx. My story is totally different but....I have only had chemo and no surgeries yet. I had 6 months of chemo with the intent downstage the tumors  including a 6+cm  on the left side. I had a mri after the first 3 months of A/C and the tumors have responded very well. Most were at least 1/2 the size as before surgery.  The BS said that if I respond as well to the taxol, she will most likely be able to do just a lumpectomy. Since I have lymph node involvement, radiation is a given, regardless of what type of surgery. I had another MRI last week and will meet with the BS this week to review the results and finalize surgery plan.  Yesterday I re-read the surgery section in Susan Love's Breast Book and she basically convinced me that given the choice, opt for breast conserving surgery and not the BMX.  So I think I have made up my mind. The only caveat is that once the bs starts digging in,she may find other stuff. For those of you who have yet to start chemo, do not fret. After completing 12 weeks of A/c and 12 weeks of T/H.  While it was not the party of my life, I did survive and you will too.
Posts.Title: JULY MASTECTOMY orchidgal rosesrx

Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2010 05:20PM nkrun wrote: Iowasue44 Congrats on going back to work so soon. I've only taken 4 days off work during chemo but plan on enjoying a full month off for the surgery. My plan was poison, cut and burn which I understand maybe typical for stage 3 but not for 1 and 2.. Seems everyone I talk to is cut, burn, poison.  I'm constantly defending my plan.  Everyone asks "didn't they just want to cut it out first and don't you just want to cut them off?"   I guess the dowstaging, breast preserving surgery then rads is not universally accepted.

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2010 10:35AM nkrun wrote: I got my pathology report back from the surgery and there were no cancer cells found in any of the tissue that was removed.  None. Wow the onc and I were truly shocked as I started out with six confirmed positive tumors in my left breast and one in a lymph node past the sentinel node. I was skeptical about neo adjuvant chemo but now I'm a believer.  Six months seemed like a long time to be getting chemo but it looks like it did its stuff. At this point I'm not sure how much of the cancer eradication was related to me, to science or to a higher power. I wish the good path report would alleviate the need for radiation but the onc says no-still need 6 weeks of rad.  Bring it on I say!
Posts.Title: JULY MASTECTOMY orchidgal rosesrx

Posts.Content: Aug 1, 2010 10:24PM nkrun wrote: Yeah surgery is over.  One night in the hospital and 1 drain. The BS removed about 1/4 of my left breast and all the lymph nodes on the left side.  The surgery was less of a ordeal than the preop mri/ultrasound localization procedure.  The radiologist via mri and ultrasound put long thin localization wires in the tumor "clips".  The clips were placed in all my tumors when they were biopsied back in November 2009. Since chemo killed all but one tumor, the clip localization procedure was used to locate the previous cancerous area.  I will find out about margins in a week or so. Did anyone else have the MRI guided localization?  Thank goodness to those of you who recommended the cami with the drain holder. I just love it.

Posts.Content: Sep 30, 2010 01:30AM nkrun wrote: 1marmalade-Regarding the creme...my rad onc prescribed x-clair and I starting applying 3xday beginning on day one. Dutchgirl-thanks for the recipe for the saline solution. I will have to try it. Caltex- yes my feet hurt like crazy. I was attributing the pain to 3 months of taxol but it seems to be getting worse even after chemo has stopped.  The pain seems to be worse right after I get up from either sleeping of sitting for a long period of time.  I am a very active person and the sore feet thing is starting to crimp my lifestyle. So sorry to hear about September rad sisters who have to drive long distances for radiation. I am extremely fortunate to have a university cancer center that is less than 1 mile from work.  I scheduled most of my appointments around my lunch hour so I can take a leisurely walk to and from the center.  Typically a coworker will join me for the walk and we will get frozen yogurt after wards. Since Dec 2009, I've walked to the cancer probably 100 times. It is so much a part of my daily routine, but I cannot say I will miss it when it is gone. Today is 12 of 33 rads.  I'm starting to feel a little burning and not a whole lot of fatigue. I have an entry in the Nike Women's 1/2 marathon (walking i time)  on Oct 17 so I really hope the burning, pain and fatigue does not get much worse.
Posts.Title: September 2010 Rads dutchgirl6 Teka
